div.p: NARRATOR: People making high-risk choices often have hangovers and may quickly learn that another drink eases their symptoms.

NARRATOR: Most people don't consider having a bloody mary, screwdriver, or beer as a hangover cure to be serious. Yet, drinking to ease a hangover is very similar to drinking to cure withdrawal, just on a smaller scale.
NARRATOR: There's a reason why alcohol can help to relieve a hangover. Alcohol initially produces a depressant effect on the central nervous system.

NARRATOR: Then it produces a mild "rebound," or stimulant effect, which can cause some degree of restlessness, nervousness, or shaking. The more a person drinks on any day, the greater the rebound effect.
NARRATOR: If we've have had a large amount to drink, the rebound will be noticeable. We'll feel slightly nervous or agitated the next morning, even though the alcohol itself is out of our system.

NARRATOR: If we take another drink to relieve this nervousness, the drink provides a mild depressant effect and makes us feel more comfortable. Not all hangover symptoms are signs of this rebound effect.
NARRATOR: For example, dry mouth, headache, and nausea can result from other factors; here we're only talking about nervous agitation.
NARRATOR: To help understand this rebound effect, think about what happens when we hold a beach ball under water. The surface of the water is like the normal level of nervous system activity.

NARRATOR: Below the water represents a low level of nervous system activity, and above the water is like hyperactivity. When we push the ball down and let it go, it doesn't just go to the surface--it rebounds above the surface.
NARRATOR: This effect is similar to what happens with our nervous system.
NARRATOR: Once someone experiences the rebound, that person may begin using alcohol or other drugs to counter the stimulant effects, leading to a pattern of using multiple drugs.

NARRATOR: And this rebound is not limited to alcohol or other depressant drugs. If a person has been taking stimulants such as cocaine or methamphetamine, then the rebound effect is depression, and it can occur very quickly.
